facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos.165-168 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos.165-168 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated August 25, 1962 of Patna High Court in Criminal Revisions Nos. 527 to 530 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1962 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revisions Nos. 527 to 530 of 1962.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed four revision applications preferred by four sets of appellants.

anchor.surface_text: A companymon question arises in these appeals from a judgment of the Patna High Court dismissing four revision applications preferred before it by four sets of appellants in the appeals before us.

facts.text: Four informations lodged at police station Ghora Saha on April 14, 1960 by different persons against different appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Four informations were lodged at the police station, Ghora Saha on April 14, 1960 by different persons against the different appellants in these cases

facts.text: Similar information lodged against some appellants by Mali Ram.

anchor.surface_text: and a similar information was lodged against some of the appellants by one Mali Ram.

facts.text: Allegations: each set of accused armed with deadly weapons went to shops of informants, demanded large sums of money, threatened death if not paid.

anchor.surface_text: In all these cases the allegations made by the informants were that each set of the accused persons armed with deadly weapons went to the shops of the various informants, demanded from them large sums of money and threatened them with death if they failed to pay the amounts demanded by them.

facts.text: Some informants paid part of money and given time to pay balance, some agreed to pay amounts demanded.

anchor.surface_text: The informations also stated that some of these persons paid part of the money and were given time to pay the balance while some agreed to pay the amounts demanded.

facts.text: Offences under s. 392 IPC registered by station officer upon informations.

anchor.surface_text: Upon informations given by these persons offences under s. 392, Indian Penal Code, were registered by the station officer

facts.text: After investigation, five challans lodged by station officer in court of Magistrate First Class at Motihari.

anchor.surface_text: and after investigation five challans were lodged by him, in the companyrt of Magistrate. First Class at Motihari.

facts.text: One case ended in acquittal, date of judgment not informed.

anchor.surface_text: One of the cases ended in an acquittal but we have number been informed of the date of the judgment in that case.

facts.text: In other four cases, trial closed for judgment after examination of all prosecution and defence witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: In the other four cases trial had companye to a close in that all the prosecution witnesses and the defence witnesses had been examined and the cases had been closed for judgment.

facts.text: Challan in case against appellants in Crl. A. 165/1962 presented on October 27, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In the case against the appellants in Crl. A. 165 of 1962 the challan was presented on October 27, 1960.

facts.text: On October 27, 1960, charges framed u/s 302 IPC against Thakur Ram and Jagarnath Pd., pleaded not guilty.

anchor.surface_text: Date of order Order with the Office action No. or proceeding signature of taken with the Court date 1.27-10-1960 All the 4 accused are present Heard both sides. It is argued on behalf of the prosecution that it is a fit case for adopting procedure under Chapter XVIII Cr. P. C. and also that the entire occurrence relates to offences companymitted on 4 dates so that all of them cannot be dealt with in a single case. Discussed law point Charge u s 302, I.P.C. framed against accused Thakur Ram and Jagarnath Pd. and explained to them. They plead number guilty.

facts.text: Trial dragged on for nearly 15 months.

anchor.surface_text: The trial dragged on for nearly 15 months and then the prosecution made an application to the companyrt for framing a charge under S. 386 or s. 387, Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Prosecution applied on January 25, 1962 for framing charge u/s 386 or 387 IPC and committing to Sessions Court; Magistrate refused.

anchor.surface_text: This was disposed of by the learned Magistrate on January 25, 1962. The relevant portion of his order sheet of that date reads thus Accused absent. A petition for their representation u s 540-A, Cr P.C. is filed. Allowed. No reference book is produced. Persued the record. The prosecution has pressed to refer the case to the Court of Sessions u s 386 or 387 P.C.

facts.text: On February 28, 1962 prosecution moved petition for stay of proceedings to prefer revision; stay refused.

anchor.surface_text: On February 28, 1962 the prosecution moved a petition for stay of proceedings on the ground that it wanted to prefer an application for revision of the order of January 25, 1962. Stay was refused and the case was proceeded with.

facts.text: On March 17, 1962 defence case closed, fixed for arguments on March 29, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On March 17, 1962 the defence case was closed and the case was fixed for March 29, 1962 for arguments.

facts.text: On March 29, 1962 second application for commitment to Sessions; ordered put up on March 30, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On that date a second application was made for companymitting the case to a companyrt of Sessions. It would appear from the order sheet of March 29, 1962 that the Magistrate heard the parties and ordered the case to be put up on the next day, that is March 30, 1962.

facts.text: On March 30, 1962 Magistrate rejected prosecution prayer for commitment u/s 386 or 387 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On this day the Magistrate passed an order to the following effect 30-3-62-All the 2 accused persons are present. Having carefully gone through the law points and section 236 Cr.P.C. I do number find that it is a case exclusively companying u s 386 or 387 I.P.C. Hence the prosecution prayer is rejected.

facts.text: Revision application preferred by Sagarmal, informant in one of the other cases, to Sessions Judge Champaran.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately thereafter a revision application was preferred, number by the prosecution, but by Sagarmal, an informant in one of the other three cases.

facts.text: Sessions Judge directed each case to be tried by Court of Sessions and commit accused accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge, Champaran, after briefly reciting the facts and reasons on which the order of the trying Magistrate was founded, disposed of the revision application in the following words .lm15 The cases are of very serious nature and the framing of charges under sections 386 or 387, I.P.C. can- number be ruled out altogether. Consequently, I direct that each of these cases should be tried by a Court of Session.

facts.text: Appellants preferred revision to Patna High Court against Sessions Judge order; main ground no jurisdiction without discharge order.

anchor.surface_text: An application for revision was preferred by the appellants before the High Court and the main ground urged on their behalf was that the Sessions Judge had numberjurisdiction to pass an order for companymitment as there was numberorder of discharge by the Magistrate.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed revision applications, holding Sessions Judge had jurisdiction as refusal to frame s.386/387 charge amounted to discharge.

anchor.surface_text: After referring to some decisions and relying upon two decisions of the Allahabad High Court the learned Judge who disposed of the revision application observed as follows As I have already indicated, in the instant cases, the trial Magistrate, after hearing the parties, refused to frame a charge for the major offence under section 386 or S. 387 of the Indian Penal Code. The refusal by the Magistrate to frame a charge under section 386 or 387 of the Indian Penal Code was a final order and it amounted to an order of discharge of the accused of the offence under those sections.

facts.text: Appellants came to Supreme Court by special leave after certificate rejected.

anchor.surface_text: An application was made for a certificate of fitness to appeal to this Court. That was rejected and the appellants have companye here by special leave.
Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1962 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revisions Nos. 527 to 530 of 1962.

arguments.claim: s.437 CrPC enacted to prevent inferior courts clutching jurisdiction and miscarriage where grave offence possible

anchor.surface_text: It is to obviate such a companysequence and to prevent inferior companyrts from clutching at jurisdiction that the provisions of s. 437, Cr.P.C. have been enacted.

holdings.text: We agree and are, therefore, of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to make an order directing the Magistrate to commit the case for trial by a Court of Sessions.

anchor.surface_text: We agree and are, therefore, of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to make an order directing the Magistrate to commit the case for trial by a Court of Sessions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects Allahabad HC view requiring express discharge; follows Madras HC Full Bench; purposive reading of s.437 to prevent inferior courts trying grave sessions offences; refusal to frame/commit implies discharge; power exercisable during trial pendency per s.347 but revision independent.

holdings.text: The refusal by the Magistrate to frame a charge under section 386 or 387 of the Indian Penal Code was a final order and it amounted to an order of discharge of the accused of the offence under those sections.

anchor.surface_text: The refusal by the Magistrate to frame a charge under section 386 or 387 of the Indian Penal Code was a final order and it amounted to an order of discharge of the accused of the offence under those sections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court holding affirmed by Supreme Court; akin to implied discharge for sessions offence when Magistrate proceeds on minor charge.

holdings.text: The provisions of S. 437, however, do not make it obligatory upon a Sessions Judge or a District Magistrate to order commitment in every case. The law gives a discretion to the revising authority and that discretion has to be exercised judicially.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of S. 437, however, do not make it obligatory upon a Sessions Judge or a District Magistrate to order commitment in every case. The law gives a discretion to the revising authority and that discretion has to be exercised judicially.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of wide terms in s.437 confers judicial discretion, not mandatoriness; consider case-specific factors.

holdings.text: In our opinion it was injudicious for the learned Sessions Judge to order the commitment of the appellants particularly so without giving any thought to the aspects of the matter to which we have adverted.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it was injudicious for the learned Sessions Judge to order the commitment of the appellants particularly so without giving any thought to the aspects of the matter to which we have adverted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advanced trial stage (closed for judgment after 15 months), belated prosecution applications rejected twice, revision by private informant lacking locus in police challan case; would cause harassment and fresh trial.

holdings.text: In a case which has proceeded on a police report a private party has really no locus standi.

anchor.surface_text: In a case which has proceeded on a police report a private party has really no locus standi.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State prosecutes police-reported cases as custodian of public interest; private revision risks vengeance.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the language of S. 437 from which it could be said that this power is not exercisable during the pendency of a trial before a Magistrate or that this power can be exercised only where the Magistrate has made an express order of discharge.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the language of S. 437 from which it could be said that this power is not exercisable during the pendency of a trial before a Magistrate or that this power can be exercised only where the Magistrate has made an express order of discharge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis; consistent with s.347 commitment power before judgment; prevents post-judgment bar u/s.403.

holdings.text: In each case, therefore the Magistrate holding the preliminary inquiry, has to be satisfied that a prima facie case is made out against the accused by the evidence of witnesses entitled to a reasonable degree of credit and unless he is so satisfied, he is not to commit.

anchor.surface_text: In each case, therefore the Magistrate holding the preliminary inquiry, has to be satisfied that a prima facie case is made out against the accused by the evidence of witnesses entitled to a reasonable degree of credit and unless he is so satisfied, he is not to commit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Supreme Court precedent in Ramgopal Ganpatrai; Magistrate not to weigh evidence fully or choose between two views but assess prima facie sufficiency.

anchor.surface_text: The refusal by the Magistrate to frame a charge under section 386 or 387 of the Indian Penal Code was a final order and it amounted to an order of discharge of the accused of the offence under those sections.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of S. 437, however, do not make it obligatory upon a Sessions Judge or a District Magistrate to order commitment in every case. The law gives a discretion to the revising authority and that discretion has to be exercised judicially.

In our opinion it was injudicious for the learned Sessions Judge to order the commitment of the appellants particularly so without giving any thought to the aspects of the matter to which we have adverted.
